The very best information and measure of this world outbreak are the grim statistics on death rates per million people. The number of cases in a country is a poor measure because it is highly influenced by the amount of testing and who is tested. The link below is to a graphical representation of this statistic. Italy is often used as an example of a worst case scenario. However this graph shows that Spain is much worse. Sweden has tried to ignore the virus with minimal to no controls and is on a trajectory that matches Italy. The US and Canada are not that much different, and are following a trajectory of deaths doubling every 3 days. Not good.So where does that leave Mexico? Mexico either due to inaccurate reporting of COVID deaths or a delayed outbreak is in the early days of the epidemic. Because this graph is logarithmic it does not start at zero, but instead starts when there are 0.1 deaths per million people. Mexico is only 7 days into this window, while the US is at 23 days, and Canada at 19 days. However the bad news is that Mexico seems to be following the same doubling every 3 days trajectory of the US and Canada. If there is no change in trajectory, Mexico could be at 100 deaths per million in just a month from now. That would be a cumulative number of 13,000 deaths. Not good.So how long does it last? It seems based on the experience of others, although some of it is considered suspect data, the curve seems to flatten out at 60 days. So perhaps in about 2 months for Mexico. Will it be over then? Not really. A vaccine is still probably a year or more away.Notice on this graph that there is a link in the bottom left corner. You can use that to turn on or turn off your choice of countries to be highlighted on the graph.https://tinyurl.com/t5vbxb7Is there any good news in this? Yes, I think so. I think the death numbers being thrown around in the US (100,000 to 200,000) and Canada (6,000 to 30,000) are much too high. I suspect the US will level off in the 120 per million range, and Canada possibly a bit lower at 100 per million. That is more like 35,000 for the US and 2,000 for Canada. I sure hope this is correct and our governments are not. In any case those are my predictions. We are not counting on being able to go to Mexico this coming winter unless there is a big surprise in the development of a vaccine.Edited: 1:29 pm, April 05, 2020

Trip Advisor is not the best place to get predictions regarding when it will be safe to travel to Huatulco. Lots of uninformed opinions here and even the experts haven't done a great job with predicting what is going to happen with this pandemic.The journal Nature is one of the top science publications in the world and a recent article states that a vaccine might be available in 12 to 18 months if everything goes well. However, a vaccine will not be required for travel to resume again. It also depends on how things progress with respect to the persistence of the virus in the population, and the development of rapid detection devices and effective anti-virals. Don't forget that a vaccine was never developed for SARS or MERS along other viral diseases that you might encounter in Mexico (e.g Dengue and Chikungunya). It's a shame regarding that taxi driver homicide but I'm not sure that's got anything to do with COVID-19. We will know much more over the next several months as to when a trip to Huatulco will be "safe" again. Even then, "safe" is perceived on an individual basis.

We don't know everything about COVID-19, but we do know that it is much more contagious than SARS. COVID is only now being contained due to an extraordinary world wide lockdown. All of the efforts to "flatten the curve" just keep people from getting in contact with the virus, which means nobody gets any immunity. Unless the lockdown is lifted in a very controlled and slow manner, we will go into a full blown epidemic again. Flight attendants are demanding masks, visors, and full body suits to work on a plane, and I don't blame them. I don't see insurance companies providing heath insurance that covers COVID, or general travel insurance until there is a vaccine. And, I don't see the likes of WestJet, Sunwing, and Transat offering packages either. I still think January 2021 is being very optimistic for normal travel to resume. I hope I am wrong!
